summary.en: â€œDedicatorsâ€ means people who dedicate something to someone or something (e.g., the people who write a book dedication).

definition.en: people who dedicate something (such as a book, building, work of art, or their time/effort) to a person, cause, or purpose; people who make a dedication

examples.en: The bookâ€™s dedicators thanked their families and teachers in the opening pages.
As dedicators of the memorial, they spoke about peace and remembrance.
Many dedicators choose a short, personal message in the dedication section.

summary.en: Dedicatory means â€œmade as a dedicationâ€ or â€œa dedication message,â€ often in formal or literary contexts.

definition.en: Written or spoken as a dedication; meant to honor someone (often at the beginning of a book, speech, or event).

examples.en: The novel opens with a dedicatory note to the authorâ€™s parents.
She gave a short dedicatory speech before the concert began.

definition.en: A dedicatory message, statement, or speech.

examples.en: The first page contains a dedicatory to his teacher.

summary.en: Dedicature is a rare, old-fashioned noun meaning â€œdedication,â€ the act or words of dedicating something to someone.

definition.en: (Rare/archaic) the act of dedicating something; a dedication.

examples.en: The poet wrote a short dedicature at the front of the book.

summary.en: Dedifferentiate means (in biology) to lose or cause the loss of specialized cell features and return to a more unspecialized state.

definition.en: (Biology) To lose specialized features and return to a more basic, unspecialized cell state.

examples.en: In some plants, mature cells can dedifferentiate and form a callus in tissue culture.
After injury, certain cells may dedifferentiate to help repair damaged tissue.
Researchers study how cells dedifferentiate to improve regenerative medicine.

definition.en: (Biology) To cause cells or tissues to lose specialized characteristics and become more primitive in structure or function.

examples.en: Some signals can dedifferentiate muscle cells in experimental animals.
The treatment aims to dedifferentiate certain cells before guiding them into a new cell type.

summary.en: Dedifferentiated means a cell (or tissue) has reverted from a specialized state to a less specialized one, especially in biology.

definition.en: (Biology) Having changed from a specialized (mature) state back to a less specialized, more â€œstemâ€‘likeâ€ state.

examples.en: Some cancer cells become dedifferentiated and start growing more aggressively.
After injury, certain tissues show dedifferentiated cells that help with repair.

definition.en: (Botany) Describing a plant cell or tissue that returns to a simpler state and can divide again, often forming callus in tissue culture.

examples.en: In plant tissue culture, dedifferentiated cells can form a callus on the medium.
A dedifferentiated plant cell may later develop into roots or shoots under the right hormones.

summary.en: â€œDedifferentiatingâ€ means becoming (or making something become) less specialized again, especially in biology.

definition.en: (Biology) Becoming less specialized again; returning from a specialized cell type to a more general, stem-like state.

examples.en: Some plant cells are capable of dedifferentiating after injury and then forming new tissue.
Researchers studied dedifferentiating muscle cells to understand how regeneration might be improved.
The team observed cells dedifferentiating into a stem-like state under certain signals.

definition.en: Causing something to become less specialized again (used before a noun in scientific writing).

examples.en: The paper discusses dedifferentiating signals in the tumor environment.
They tested a dedifferentiating treatment on cultured cells.

summary.en: Dedifferentiation means cells becoming less specialized, often returning to a more basic state.

definition.en: (Biology) the process in which specialized (mature) cells lose their specialized features and return to a more basic, unspecialized state, often regaining the ability to divide.

examples.en: In some animals, dedifferentiation allows injured tissue to rebuild during regeneration.
Plant cells can undergo dedifferentiation in tissue culture and form a callus.

definition.en: (Broader/medical use) a change in which cells or tissues become less specialized, sometimes associated with disease processes such as cancer.

examples.en: Researchers studied whether tumor cells show signs of dedifferentiation over time.
The report discusses dedifferentiation as one possible pathway to abnormal cell growth.

summary.en: Designation means an official title/label, or the act of officially naming or assigning something.

definition.en: a title, name, or label given to someone or something; an official description of a job or role

examples.en: What is your job designation at the company?
â€œDr.â€ is a designation that shows someone has earned a doctoral degree.
The product has an eco-friendly designation on the packaging.

definition.en: the act of choosing or officially naming someone or something for a particular purpose

examples.en: The committee approved the designation of the new team leader.
The area received designation as a national park.

summary.en: A rare legal term meaning a commission (authorization), especially to take testimony; short for *dedimus potestatem*.

definition.en: (Law, historical) A written commission authorizing someone to perform a specific actâ€”especially to take testimony or conduct an examination outside court; short for *dedimus potestatem*.

examples.en: The attorney requested a dedimus to take the witnessâ€™s deposition overseas.
In older case files, the clerk noted that a dedimus had been issued for examination of the defendant.

summary.en: Dedit is Latin for â€œ(he/she/it) gave / has given.â€

definition.en: a Latin verb form meaning â€œ(he/she/it) gaveâ€ or â€œhas given,â€ from the verb *dare* (â€œto giveâ€).

examples.en: In Latin class, we translated *dedit* as â€œhe gave.â€
The inscription says *Deus dedit*, meaning â€œGod gave (it).â€

summary.en: Dietitian: a nutrition professional who advises people on healthy eating and meal planning.

definition.en: A trained professional who gives expert advice about food, nutrition, and healthy eating, often working in hospitals, clinics, schools, or public health.

examples.en: My doctor referred me to a dietitian to manage my diabetes through food choices.
The dietitian created a meal plan that fit my allergies and my budget.
In the hospital, a dietitian checks whether patients are getting the right nutrition.

summary.en: Dediticiancy means the status of a surrendered person (a *dediticius*), mainly used in Roman-law or historical contexts.

definition.en: the condition or status of being a *dediticius*â€”a person who has surrendered and is placed under another power, especially in Roman law and historical writing.

examples.en: In the text, prisoners who accepted unconditional surrender were reduced to dediticiancy.
The historian compares citizenship with dediticiancy to show how rights could be lost.

summary.en: â€œDeditionâ€ is a rare formal noun meaning complete surrender.

definition.en: (Rare, formal) the act of surrendering completely; giving oneself up to another power or authority.

examples.en: After months of fighting, the army accepted dedition and laid down its weapons.
The treaty demanded dedition of the fortress within three days.

â€œDedo del pieâ€ specifically means â€œtoe.â€

summary.en: Dedogmatize means to make something less rigidly dogmatic by removing strict, unquestioned beliefs.

definition.en: to make (a person, institution, or idea) less dogmatic; to remove strict, unquestioned beliefs from something

examples.en: The new curriculum aims to dedogmatize history classes by encouraging debate and multiple perspectives.
Some leaders tried to dedogmatize the organization after years of rigid rules.

summary.en: Desolation means extreme emptiness or sadness, or an empty, bleak place.

definition.en: A state of great emptiness, loneliness, or sadness; a feeling that something is abandoned or ruined.

examples.en: After the storm, there was a sense of desolation in the townâ€”broken windows and empty streets.
She felt desolation when her close friend moved away.

definition.en: A place that is empty, bleak, and lacking life; a wasteland.

examples.en: They crossed a desolation of rock and sand with no trees in sight.

summary.en: Dedolence is a rare noun meaning freedom from pain or grief, sometimes implying emotional numbness.

definition.en: freedom from pain or grief; a state of being without sorrow.

examples.en: After hearing the good news, she felt a quiet dedolence for the first time in months.
The poem moves from grief to dedolence, ending with calm acceptance.

definition.en: (rare) emotional numbness or insensitivity, as if pain cannot be felt.

examples.en: He spoke of the loss with a strange dedolence that worried his friends.

summary.en: Dedolency is a very rare, old-fashioned noun meaning deep sorrow or grief.

definition.en: (Very rare/archaic) sorrow; grief; a feeling of pain or distress.

examples.en: After the loss, a quiet dedolency settled over the house.
The poem is written in a tone of dedolency rather than anger.

summary.en: Dedolent means pleasantly fragrant, or filled with a noticeable smell (often used in formal or literary writing).

definition.en: (formal) Having a pleasant smell; fragrant.

examples.en: The garden was dedolent with roses after the rain.
A dedolent breeze carried the scent of pine through the open window.

definition.en: (literary, of a place or thing) Filled with a particular smell, often strongly so.

examples.en: The kitchen was dedolent of garlic and warm bread.
The old library felt dedolent of paper, dust, and quiet history.

summary.en: Dedolomitic means â€˜related to rocks changed from dolomite toward calcite,â€™ a geology term.

definition.en: (Geology) Describing rock (especially limestone) that has been altered from dolomite back toward calcite, or relating to the process of this change (dedolomitization).

examples.en: The core shows a dedolomitic zone where the original dolomite has been partly replaced by calcite.
Dedolomitic textures can form when groundwater chemistry changes over long periods.

summary.en: Dedolomitization is the process where dolomite is altered and replaced by calcite in rocks.

definition.en: a geological/chemical process in which dolomite (a calciumâ€“magnesium carbonate rock or mineral) is converted back into calcite (calcium carbonate), often during rock alteration underground.

examples.en: Dedolomitization can change a rockâ€™s porosity and affect groundwater flow.
The core samples show dedolomitization near fractures where fluids moved through the rock.

summary.en: â€œDedolomitization-relatedâ€ means connected with the geological process of dolomite changing back into calcite.

definition.en: Connected with dedolomitization, a geological process in which dolomite rock is altered back into calcite (often during interaction with calcium-rich water).

examples.en: The report describes dedolomitization-related changes in porosity that affected groundwater flow.
We sampled dedolomitization-related calcite veins near the old quarry.

summary.en: To chemically alter dolomite into limestone by removing magnesium.

definition.en: (Geology) To change dolomite rock into limestone (or a more calcite-rich rock) by removing magnesium, usually through chemical alteration by water.

examples.en: Groundwater can dedolomitize dolomite beds over long periods of time.
In the core samples, the lower unit is dedolomitized and contains more calcite than dolomite.

summary.en: A geology term meaning â€˜converted from dolomite back to limestone (calcite).â€™

definition.en: (Geology) Changed from dolomite rock back into limestone (calcite) by chemical processes, usually involving the removal of magnesium during waterâ€“rock interaction.

examples.en: The core sample shows a dedolomitized zone near fractures where groundwater circulated.
Dedolomitized limestone can have different porosity than the original dolomite.

summary.en: â€œDedolomitizingâ€ means converting dolomite into calcite, or describing something that causes that change.

definition.en: (Geology) changing dolomite rock or dolomite cement into calcite (limestone) through chemical reactions, usually involving water and dissolved ions.

examples.en: In some aquifers, groundwater can be dedolomitizing the bedrock and altering its porosity.
The lab results suggest the solution is dedolomitizing the sample, producing more calcite.

definition.en: describing a fluid, environment, or process that causes dolomite to convert to calcite.

examples.en: A dedolomitizing fluid can leave a distinct calcite texture in the rock.
They mapped dedolomitizing zones near the fracture network.

summary.en: Dedra is a female first name, commonly used as a variant spelling of Deirdre/Deidre.

definition.en: A feminine given name; a spelling variant of Deidre/Deirdre used in English-speaking contexts.

examples.en: Dedra moved to Chicago after college.
Have you met Dedra from the marketing team?

summary.en: Dedric is a male first name, a variant of Dedrick, related to Dietrich and often understood as â€œruler of the people.â€

definition.en: a male given name (first name), a variant spelling of "Dedrick/Dedric," related to the Germanic name Dietrich, often interpreted as â€œruler of the people.â€

examples.en: Dedric is starting a new job next week.
I met Dedric at a community meeting.

summary.en: â€œDedrickâ€ is a proper name used as a first name (more common) or a surname.

definition.en: A male given name (first name), used especially in the U.S.; also spelled as a variant of â€œDedrick/Diedrick/Dietrich.â€

examples.en: Dedrick moved to Chicago for a new job.
Our teacher, Mr. Dedrick, teaches history.

definition.en: A family name (surname/last name), less commonly used than the first name.

examples.en: I met Dr. Dedrick at the conference.
The Dedrick family has lived here for generations.

summary.en: Dedrik is usually a male personal name, a spelling variant of Dedrick/Dedric.

definition.en: A male given name (a variant spelling of Dedrick/Dedric), used as a personal name.

examples.en: Dedrik is starting a new job next week.
I met Dedrik at a community event.

summary.en: Deduce means to figure something out by reasoning from facts, clues, or rules.

definition.en: to reach an answer or conclusion by reasoning from known facts or evidence

examples.en: From the wet streets, we deduced that it had rained recently.
Detectives try to deduce what happened from small clues.

definition.en: to logically infer a specific result from a general rule or principle

examples.en: If all humans need water, we can deduce that travelers must carry water.
The formula lets you deduce the missing value.

summary.en: Deduce most commonly means to reason out a conclusion from facts; it can also mean to subtract or take away (especially money or points).

definition.en: to figure out or reach an answer by using known facts and logical reasoning (not by guessing)

examples.en: From the footprints, the detective deduced that someone had entered through the back door.
I deduced the meaning of the new word from the context.
We can deduce that sales will rise if prices drop.

definition.en: to take away or subtract an amount (often money or points), especially from a total

examples.en: Please deduct the shipping cost from the refund.
The teacher deducted two points for late work.

summary.en: â€œDeducedâ€ means â€œinferred by reasoning from evidence,â€ and it is the past form of â€œdeduce.â€

definition.en: to reach a conclusion by reasoning from known facts; to infer

examples.en: From the footprints, the detective deduced that someone had entered through the window.
We deduced that the meeting was canceled because no one showed up.
Scientists deduced the planetâ€™s mass from its effect on nearby objects.

definition.en: inferred or concluded from evidence (used as an adjective)

examples.en: The deduced meaning of the poem depends on the readerâ€™s experience.
Their deduced timeline matched the security footage.

summary.en: Deducement is a rare noun meaning either (1) a deduction/inference, or (2) an older sense: an inducement that persuades someone to act.

definition.en: the act or process of deducing (reasoning from facts to reach a conclusion); a deduction or inference

examples.en: From the footprints in the snow, her deducement was that someone had been there overnight.
His deducement relies on the evidence we already have, not on guesses.

definition.en: (older/rare) something that persuades or leads someone toward an action; an inducement

examples.en: Promises of quick profit were used as a deducement to invest.
They offered a discount as a deducement for new customers to sign up.

summary.en: A deducer is someone who deducesâ€”uses facts and logic to reach a conclusion.

definition.en: a person or thing that deduces (reaches a conclusion by reasoning from facts or evidence); someone who infers.

examples.en: As a careful deducer, she checked each clue before making a claim.
Sherlock Holmes is often portrayed as a brilliant deducer.

summary.en: DedÅ«cere is a Latin verb meaning â€œto lead down/away,â€ and by extension â€œto derive or infer,â€ giving rise to English words like deduce and deduct.

definition.en: (Latin) to lead or bring down; to lead away or escort.

examples.en: The guide promised to deducere the visitors from the hill safely.
In old texts, a leader may deducere a group out of danger.

definition.en: (Latin) to derive, trace out, or infer (the idea behind modern English â€œdeduceâ€).

examples.en: From these facts, you can deducere a reasonable conclusion.
Scholars deducere the rule from repeated examples.

definition.en: (Less common) to subtract or take away (a source idea related to â€œdeductâ€).

examples.en: Some writers use deducere for taking an amount away from a total.

summary.en: â€œDeducersâ€ means people who infer or conclude something by reasoning from evidence.

definition.en: People who deduce thingsâ€”who reach conclusions by reasoning from facts, evidence, or general rules.

examples.en: Scientists are careful deducers who test ideas against evidence.
Good detectives are deducers: they connect small clues to form a bigger picture.
The best deducers admit uncertainty when the facts are incomplete.

summary.en: â€œDeducesâ€ means â€œinfers or figures out a conclusion from facts or evidence.â€

definition.en: to reach an answer or form an opinion by reasoning from known facts (often: deduce something from something)

examples.en: From the footprints in the snow, she deduces that someone walked to the back door.
He deduces the meaning of the new word from the context.
The detective deduces what happened by comparing the times and locations.

definition.en: (formal) to infer a specific fact as a logical result of a general rule or principle

examples.en: From the law, the judge deduces that the contract is invalid.
From the definition, we can deduce that the two statements cannot both be true.

summary.en: Deductibility means whether something can be deducted, especially for tax purposes.

definition.en: the quality of being able to be deducted (especially from taxes, costs, or an amount owed)

examples.en: Before you donate, check the deductibility of the charity in your country.
The accountant asked about the deductibility of travel expenses.
There is some debate about the deductibility of home office costs.

summary.en: Deducible means something can be logically inferred from evidence or facts.

definition.en: Able to be figured out or concluded from known facts, evidence, or general rules.

examples.en: From the footprints in the snow, it was deducible that someone had entered the yard.
His age isnâ€™t stated, but itâ€™s deducible from the graduation year on his rÃ©sumÃ©.

summary.en: Deducibleness means the quality of being logically inferable (deducible).

definition.en: The quality of being deducible (able to be logically inferred from known facts, rules, or evidence).

examples.en: The deducibleness of the result depends on the assumptions you start with.
In logic class, we discussed the deducibleness of certain conclusions from a set of premises.

summary.en: â€œDeduciblyâ€ means â€œin a way that can be logically worked out from evidence.â€

definition.en: In a way that can be logically deduced (worked out) from known facts or evidence.

examples.en: From these records, it is deducibly clear that sales rose in the summer.
If the train was late, then his arrival time is deducibly after 9 p.m.

summary.en: â€œDeducingâ€ means inferring a conclusion from evidence or reasoning.

definition.en: figuring something out by reasoning from facts, evidence, or what you already know; inferring

examples.en: From the muddy footprints, the detective was deducing that someone had entered through the back door.
Iâ€™m deducing the meaning of this new word from the sentence.
She kept deducing the answer step by step instead of guessing.

summary.en: Deductive means using general rules to reach a specific conclusion; it can also describe a rule-first teaching/writing style.

definition.en: (Commonly spelled â€œdeductiveâ€) Using reasoning that starts from general rules or facts and reaches a specific conclusion.

examples.en: Deductive reasoning starts with a rule and applies it to a case.
From the fact that all mammals breathe air, she made a deductive conclusion that whales breathe air too.

definition.en: (Of teaching or writing) Organized so that a main principle is stated first, then supported with details and examples.

examples.en: The textbook uses a deductive approach: it explains the grammar rule first and then gives exercises.

summary.en: â€œDeductâ€ most commonly means to take away an amount from a total, especially money or points; it can also mean to subtract in math or to deduce by reasoning.

definition.en: to take away an amount (often money, points, or a number) from a total

examples.en: The store will deduct $10 from your bill if you use this coupon.
The teacher deducted two points for each spelling mistake.

definition.en: to subtract one number from another

examples.en: Deduct 5 from 12 to get 7.

definition.en: to figure out or conclude something by reasoning (often used with â€œfromâ€)

examples.en: From his tone, I deduced that he was upset.

summary.en: â€œDeductedâ€ means taken away from a total, often money, points, or taxes withheld.

definition.en: subtracted or taken away from a total amount (for example, money, points, or time)

examples.en: $20 was deducted from my paycheck for health insurance.
The store deducted the discount at checkout.
Five points were deducted for a wrong answer.

definition.en: withheld (especially for taxes, fees, or automatic payments)

examples.en: Taxes were deducted before the salary was deposited.
A service fee is deducted each month.

summary.en: Deductibility means whether something can legally be deducted, especially for tax purposes.

definition.en: the quality or condition of being deductible (able to be subtracted, especially from taxable income or a total amount)

examples.en: Check the deductibility of your work-related expenses before you file your taxes.
The deductibility of home office costs depends on your situation and local tax rules.

summary.en: â€œDeductibleâ€ most often means the amount you pay before insurance starts paying; it can also mean an expense that is allowed to be subtracted for tax purposes.

definition.en: (Insurance) the amount of money you must pay yourself before an insurance company starts to pay for the rest.

examples.en: My health plan has a $1,000 deductible.
If the repair costs less than your deductible, insurance wonâ€™t pay anything.
We chose a higher deductible to lower the monthly premium.

definition.en: (Tax) an expense or amount that can be subtracted from your income when calculating how much tax you owe.

examples.en: Charitable donations may be deductible on your tax return.
Some business travel costs are deductible expenses.

summary.en: â€œDeductiblesâ€ usually means the out-of-pocket amount you pay before insurance pays; it can also mean tax-deductible items/expenses.

definition.en: (Insurance) The amount of money you must pay yourself before an insurance company starts paying for covered costs.

examples.en: My plan has a $500 deductible, so I pay the first $500 of medical costs each year.
A higher deductible usually means a lower monthly premium.

definition.en: (Tax/accounting) Expenses or items that can be subtracted from taxable income or revenue when calculating tax.

examples.en: Charitable donations may be deductible, depending on the rules.
Keep receipts so you can claim your deductibles at tax time.

summary.en: â€œDeductibleâ€ most commonly means an insurance amount you pay before coverage begins; it can also mean â€œable to be deducted,â€ especially for taxes.

definition.en: (especially in insurance) The amount of money you must pay yourself before an insurance company starts paying.

examples.en: My health plan has a $1,000 deductible.
You pay the deductible first, and then the insurance covers the rest.

definition.en: Able to be subtracted from income or costs (for example, to reduce taxable income).

examples.en: Business meals may be tax-deductible in some cases.
Is this expense deductible on my taxes?

summary.en: â€œDeductingâ€ means subtracting or taking out an amount, especially money or points, often from a total, paycheck, or account.

definition.en: subtracting an amount from a total; taking away (money, points, or quantity).

examples.en: After deducting expenses, we made a small profit.
The teacher is deducting two points for late homework.

definition.en: withholding or taking out money (often for tax, fees, or payments) from someoneâ€™s pay or account.

examples.en: The company is deducting taxes from each paycheck.
The bank is deducting a monthly service fee.

summary.en: Deduction means (1) an amount taken away from a total, especially money, or (2) a conclusion reached by reasoning from facts.

definition.en: the act of taking an amount away from a total; something that is subtracted (often from money, taxes, or pay)

examples.en: There is a tax deduction from my paycheck every month.
After the deduction, the final price is $80.
The company made deductions for health insurance.

definition.en: a conclusion reached by reasoning from facts; an inference

examples.en: From the clues, her deduction was that the keys were still in the car.
Thatâ€™s a logical deduction based on the data.

summary.en: â€œDeductionâ€ most often means an amount taken away (especially from pay or taxes), and it can also mean a conclusion reached by reasoning.

definition.en: The act of taking something away (often money) from a total amount.

examples.en: There is a tax deduction on your paycheck every month.
After deductions, her take-home pay was much smaller.

definition.en: An amount that is subtracted from income (especially for tax purposes) to reduce the tax you pay.

examples.en: Charitable donations may qualify as a deduction.
He claimed a home-office deduction this year.

definition.en: A conclusion reached by reasoning from facts or evidence.

examples.en: From the muddy footprints, the detective made a deduction about where the thief went.
Your deduction makes sense, but we need more evidence.

summary.en: Deductionism is the belief or method of explaining and building knowledge mainly through deductionâ€”from general principles to specific conclusions.

definition.en: A way of explaining things by using deduction (reasoning from general rules to specific conclusions), often assuming that a whole system can be understood by logically deriving details from a few basic principles.

examples.en: In deductionism, scientists start with a general theory and then deduce what should happen in a specific experiment.
Critics argue that deductionism can overlook messy real-world details that donâ€™t fit the rules.

definition.en: (Philosophy) The view that knowledge or explanation should primarily be built through deductive arguments, rather than mainly from observation, induction, or probability.

examples.en: Some philosophers reject strict deductionism because many everyday beliefs come from experience rather than deduction.
The essay compares deductionism with approaches that emphasize evidence and induction.

summary.en: Deductions are either amounts subtracted (especially from pay or taxes) or conclusions reached by reasoning from evidence.

definition.en: amounts taken away or subtracted from a total, especially from money you earn (for example, taxes, insurance, or other withholdings); also, costs you can subtract from your taxable income

examples.en: Your paycheck shows deductions for taxes and health insurance.
Business travel can be one of your tax deductions.

definition.en: conclusions you reach by reasoning from facts or evidence

examples.en: The detective made several deductions from the footprints in the mud.
Her deductions were logical, but she still needed proof.

summary.en: Deductive means using general rules or known facts to logically reach a specific conclusion.

definition.en: Using logic to reach a specific conclusion from general rules or known facts.

examples.en: Deductive reasoning starts with a rule and applies it to a particular case.
The detective used a deductive approach to narrow down the suspect list.

definition.en: Relating to a style of teaching or testing that focuses on rules first, then practice.

examples.en: Some grammar lessons take a deductive method: explain the rule, then give exercises.

summary.en: â€œDeductivelyâ€ means â€œusing deductionâ€â€”moving from general principles to a specific conclusion.

definition.en: In a way that uses deduction: reasoning from general rules or principles to reach a specific, logical conclusion.

examples.en: Starting from the definition of a triangle, she deductively proved that the angles add up to 180 degrees.
The lawyer argued deductively: if the contract is invalid, then the payment is not required.

summary.en: Deductivism is the belief that deduction is the central or most dependable form of reasoning for knowledge and justification.

definition.en: A view in philosophy and logic that emphasizes deduction (reasoning from general rules to specific conclusions) as the main or most reliable way to gain knowledge or justify beliefs.

examples.en: In the seminar, deductivism was contrasted with inductivism, which relies on evidence and patterns.
The authorâ€™s deductivism leads her to start from a theory and then derive predictions to test.

summary.en: â€œDeductoryâ€ is a rare adjective meaning â€œdeductive,â€ describing reasoning from general rules to specific conclusions.

definition.en: (Rare) Using deduction; based on reasoning from general rules to a specific conclusion (similar to â€œdeductiveâ€).

examples.en: The philosopher used a deductory method to reach a clear conclusion.
In math, a deductory proof starts from accepted rules and moves step by step.

summary.en: â€œDeductsâ€ means subtracts or takes away an amount, especially money, points, or fees.

definition.en: to subtract or take away an amount from a total (usually money, points, or time)

examples.en: The store deducts the discount at checkout.
The teacher deducts two points for each spelling mistake.
Please deduct shipping costs from the refund.

definition.en: to take an amount from someoneâ€™s pay, account, or taxes (often automatically)

examples.en: The company deducts health insurance from my paycheck.
Banks may deduct a small fee each month.

summary.en: *Deductus* is a Latin form meaning â€œderived/deduced,â€ mostly seen in scholarly Latin phrases rather than everyday English.

definition.en: (Latin; used in scholarly or historical writing) â€œled down; derived; deduced.â€ It is the masculine nominative singular past participle of *dÄ“dÅ«cere* (â€œto lead down; deriveâ€).

examples.en: In a Latin note, the author calls the conclusion *deductus ex principiis* (â€œderived from principlesâ€).
The genealogy is described as *deductus* from an older source.

summary.en: â€œDeduitâ€ is not standard English; you likely mean â€œdeduceâ€ (infer a conclusion from facts).

definition.en: to reach an answer or conclusion by reasoning from known facts

examples.en: From the footprints, the detective deduced that someone had entered through the window.
I deduced that the meeting was canceled because everyone left early.

summary.en: Dedupe means to remove duplicates, especially in data or lists.

definition.en: to remove duplicate (repeated) items, especially in data, lists, or files; to deduplicate

examples.en: We need to dedupe the email list before sending the newsletter.
This tool can dedupe photos that look the same.
After merging the two spreadsheets, I deduped the rows.

summary.en: Deduplicate means to remove duplicates so only unique items remain, especially in data or lists.

definition.en: to remove repeated items so that each item appears only once (especially in a list, dataset, or text)

examples.en: We need to deduplicate the email list before sending the newsletter.
The app automatically deduplicates your photos when you upload them.
Deduplicate the records by customer ID so each person is counted once.

definition.en: to become free of duplicates; to end up with only unique items

examples.en: After cleaning, the data deduplicated nicely and was easier to analyze.
If the files deduplicate, the backup will use less storage.

summary.en: Deduplicated means duplicates have been removed or reduced (especially in data/files).

definition.en: (Adj.) Having had duplicates removed; made so that repeated copies (especially in data or files) are reduced to one.

examples.en: The dataset is deduplicated, so each customer appears only once.
Please upload the deduplicated list of emails before we send the newsletter.

definition.en: (V. past form) Past tense/past participle of â€œdeduplicateâ€: to remove or reduce duplicate copies.

examples.en: We deduplicated the backup files to save storage space.
The records have been deduplicated automatically by the system.

summary.en: Deduplication means removing duplicate data, often as a computing method to save space by keeping one copy and referencing it.

definition.en: the process of removing duplicate copies of data so only one unique version is kept

examples.en: The backup system uses deduplication to save disk space.
Email deduplication helps reduce repeated messages in the archive.

definition.en: (computing) a technique that stores or transmits only unique data blocks, replacing repeats with references

examples.en: With block-level deduplication, identical chunks are stored once and reused.
Deduplication can speed up transfers when many files share the same content.
